title: Have
body: or HAVE. Lat A form of the salutatory expression “Ave,” (hail,) in the titles of the constitutions of the Theodosian and Justinlanean Codes. Calvin; Spelman

title: Habeas Corpora Juratorum
body: A writ commanding the sheriff to bring up the persons of jurors, and, if need were, to distrain them of their lands and goods, in order to Insure or compel thelr attendance in court on tbe day of trial of a cause. It is-sued from the Common Pleas, and served the same purpose as a distringas juratores in the Klng’s Bench. It was abolished by tbe C. L. P. Act, 1852, | 104. Brown.

title: Habeas Cobpus
body: Lat. (You have the body.) The name given to a variety of writs, (of which these were anciently the em-phatlc words,) havlng for their object to bring a party before a court or Judge. In common usage, aud whenever these words are used alone, they are understood to mean the habeas corpus ad subjiciendum, (see infra

title: Habendum
body: Lat. In conveyancing. Tiie clanse usually following the granting part of the premises of a deed, which defines the extent of the ownership in the thing granted to be held and enjoyed by the gran-tee. 3 washb. Real Prop. 437; New York Indians v. U. S., 170 U. S. 1, 18 Sup. Ct. 531, 42 L. Ed. 927; Clapp v. Byrnes, 3 App. Dlv. 284, 38 N. V. Supp. 1063; Milier v. Graham

title: Habentes Homines
body: In old Eng-llsh law. Rich men; literally, having men. The same with fees ting-men, (q. v.) Cowell

title: Habentia
body: Riches, Mon. Angl. t 1, 100

title: Habere
body: Lat. In the civU law. To have. Sometimes distinguished from tenere, (to hdld,) and possidere, (to possess;) habere referring to the right, tenere to the fact, and possidere to both. Calvin

title: Habere Facias Fossessionem
body: Lat. That you cause to have possession. The name of the process commonly resorted to by the successful party in an action of ejectment, for the purpose of being placed by the sheriff in tbe actual possession of the land recovered. It is commonly termed sim-ply “habere facias:* or “hab. fa.**

title: Habere Facias Seisinam
body: L. Lat

title: Habere Facias Visum
body: Lat. That you cause to have a view. A writ to cause the sherifT to take a view of lands or tenements

title: Habere Licere
body: Lat. In Roman law. To allow [one] to have [possession.] This phrase denoted the duty of the seller of property to allow the purchaser to have the possession and enjoyment. For a breach of this duty, an actio ex empto might be main-tained

title: Haberjects
body: A cloth of a mixed color. Magna Charta, c. 26

title: Habeto Tibi Res Tuas
body: Lat. Have or take your effects to yourself, one of the old Roman forms of divorcing a wife. Cal* vin

title: Habilis
body: Lat. Fit; suitable; active; useful, (of a servant.) Proved; authentic, (of Book of Saints.) Fixed; stable, (of au-thority of the king.) Du Cange

title: Habit
body: A disposition or condition of the body or mind acquired by custom or a usual repetitlon of the same act or function. Knlckerbocker L. Ins. Co. v. Foley, 105 U. S. 354, 26 L. Ed. 1055; Conner v. Citizens’ St. R. Co., 146 Ind. 430, 45 N. E. 662; State v. Skil

title: Habitable Repair
body: A covenant by a lessee to “pat the premlses into habitable repair” binds bim to pat them into such a state that they may he occupied, not only wlth safety, but with reasonable comfort, for tbe purposes for which they are taken. Miller v. McCardell, 19 R. I. 304, 33 Ati. 445, 30 L. R. A. 682

title: Habitancy
body: Settled dwelling in a given place; fixed and permanent residence there. This term is more cpmprehenslve than “domicile,” for one may he domiciled in a given place though he does not spend the greater portion of hls time there, or though he may be absent for long periods. It is also more comprehensive than “residence,” for one mny reslde in a given place only tem-porarlly or for short periods on the occasion of repeated visits. Bnt in neither case could he properly be called an “inhabitant” of that place or be said to have hls “habitancy” there. See Atkinson v. washington & Jef-ferson College, 54 W. Va. 32, 46 S. B. 253; Hairston v. Hairston, 27 Miss. 711, 61 Am. Dec. 530; Abington v. North Bridgewater, 23 Pick. (Mass.) 170. And see Domicile; Resi-dencs

title: Habitant
body: Fr. In French and Ca-nadian law. A resident tenant; a settler; a tenant who kept hearth and home on the selgniory

title: Habitatio
body: Lat in the civU law. The right of dwelling; the right of free resi-dence in another’s house. Inst. 2, 5; Dig. 7,8

title: Habitation
body: In tbe civil law. Tbe

title: Habitual Criminal
body: By statute in several states, one who is convicted of a felony, having been previously convicted of any crime (or twice so convicted), or who is convicted of a misdemeanor and has previous-ly (in New York) been five times convicted of a misdemeanor. Crim. Code N. Y. 1903, § 510; Rev. SL Utah, 1898, g 4067. In a more gen-erai sense, one made subject to police sur-veillance and arrest on suspicion, on account of his previous criminal record and absence of honest employment

title: Habitual Drunkard
body: A person given to ebriety or the excessive use of in-toxicating drink, who has lost the power or the will, by frequent indulgence, to control his appetite for it Ludwick v. Com., 18 Pa. 174; Gourlay v. Gourlay, 16 R. I. 705, 19 Atl. 142; Miskey’s Appeal, 107 Pa. 626; Richards v. Richards, 19 UL App. 467; Mc-Bee v. McBee, 22 Or. 329, 29 Pac. 887, 29 Am. St. Rep. 613

title: Hable
body: L. Fr. In old English law. A port or harbor; a station for ships. St. 27 Hen. VI. c. 3

title: Hacienda
body: In Spanish law. The pub-lic domaln; the royal estate; the aggregate wealth of the state. The science of admin-isterlng the national wealth; public economy. Also an estate or farm belonging to a private person

title: Hackney Carriages
body: Carriages plying for hire In the street. The driver is liable for negligently losing baggage. Mas-terson v. Short, 33 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 486

title: Hadbote
body: In Saxon law. A recompense or satisfaction for the violation of holy orders, or violence offered to persons in holy orders. Cowell; Blount

title: Haderunga
body: In old English law. Hatred; ill will; prejudice, or partiality. Spelman; Cowell

title: Hadgonel
body: In old English law. A tax or mulct. Jacob

title: Hjec Est Gonventio
body: Lat This is an agreement, words with which agree-ments anciently commenced. Yearb. H. 6 Edw. II. 191

title: Hjeo Est Finalis Conoordia
body: L

title: Hjereda
body: In Gothlc law. A tribunal answering to the Engllsh court-leet

title: Hjerede Abducto
body: An anclent writ that lay for the lord, who, bavlng by right the wardship of bis tenant under age, could not obtaln his person, the same being carried

title: Hjerede Deliberando Alteri Qui Habet Custodium Terrie
body: An

title: Hjerede Rapto
body: An ancient wrlt that lay for the ravishment ot the lord's ward. Reg. orlg. 163

title: Hjeredes
body: Lat in the clvll law. Heirs. The plural of ftaeres, (q. v

title: Hsredipeta
body: Lat. In old English law. A seeker of an Inheritance; hence, the next heir to lands

title: Hjereditas
body: In Roman law. The

title: Hjeres
body: In Roman law. The heir, or universal successor in the event of death. The helr is he who actively or passively suc-eeeds to the entire property of the estate-leaver. He is not only the successor to the rights and claims, but also to the estate-leav-er’s debts, and in relation to his estate is to be regarded as the Identical person of the estate-leaver, inasmuch as he represents him in all hls active and passive relations to his estate. Mackeld. Rom. Law, $ 651

title: Hafne
body: A haven or port Cowell

title: Haga
body: A house in a city or borough. Scott

title: Hagia
body: A hedge. Mon. Angl. tom. 2, p. 273

title: Hagne
body: A little hand gun. SL 33 Hen. VIII. c. 6

title: Hagnebut
body: A hand-gun of a larger description than the hagne. St 2 & 3 Edw

title: Hata
body: In old English law. A park inclosed. Cowell

title: Haiebote
body: In old Engllsh law. A permission or lioerty to take thorns, etc., to make or repair hedges. Blount

title: Haul
body: In Scotch law. whole; the whole. “All and halll” are common words in conveyances. 1 Bell, App. Cas. 499

title: Haimsuckbn
body: In Scotch law. The crime of assaulting a person in his own house. Belt

title: Half
body: A moiety; one of two equal parts of anything susceptible of division. Prentiss v. Brewer, 17 wis. 644, 86 Am. Dec. 730; Hartford Iron Min. Co. v. Cambridge Min. Co., 80 Mich. 491, 45 N. W. 351; Cogan v. Cook, 22 Minn. 142; Dart v. Barbour, 32 Mlch. 272. Used in law in various compound terms, in substantially the same sense, as follows

title: Halifax Law
body: A synonym for lynch law, or the summary (and unauthorized) trlal of a person accused of crime and the lnfllc-tlon of death upon him; from the name of the parish of Halifax, in England, where an-dently this form of private Justlce was prac-tlsed by the free burghers in tHe case of per-sons accused of stealing; also called “gibbet law.”

title: Haligemot
body: In Saxon law. The meeting of a ball, (conventus aulce,) that is, a lord’s court; a court of a manor, or court-baron. Spelman. So called from the hall, where the tenants or freemen met, and jus-tice was administered. Crabb, Eng. Law, 26

title: Haltmas
body: In English law. The feast of All Sainis, on the 1st of November; one of the cross-quarters of the year, was computed from Hallmas to Candlemas, whar-ton

title: Hall
body: A bulldlug or room of conslder-able size, used as a place for the meeting of public assemblies, conventions, courts, etc

title: Hallage
body: In old Engllsh law. A fee or toll due for goods or merchandise vended in a hall. Jacob

title: Hallazco
body: In Spanish law. The'flnd-ing and taking possesslon of something whlch previously had no owner, and which thus becomes the property of the first occupant. Las Partidas, 3, 5, 28; 5, 48, 49 ; 5, 20, 50

title: Halle-Gemote
body: In Saxon law. Hali-gemot, (q. v

title: Hallucination
body: In medical juris-prudence. A trick or deceit of the senses; a morbld error either of the sense of sight or that of hearlng, or posslbly of the other senses; a psychological state, such as would be produced naturally by an act of sense-per-ceptlon, attrlhuted confidently, but mistaken-ly, to something which has no objective exlst-ence; as, when the patient imagines that he sees an object when there is none, or hears a voice or other sound when nothing strikes his ear. See Staples v. wellington, 58 Me. 459; Foster v. Dickerson, 64 VL 233, 24 Atl. 257; McNett v. Cooper (C. C.) 13 Fed. 590; People v. Krist, 168 N. Y. 19, 60 N. E. 1057

title: Halmote
body: See Haligemot

title: Halymote
body: A holy or ecclesiastical court

title: Halywercfolk
body: Sax, In old Eng-lish law. Tenants who held land by the service of repairing or defending a church or monument, whereby they were exempted from feudal and military services

title: Hama
body: In old Engllsh law. A hook; an engine with which a house on fire is pulled down. Yel. 60

title: Hambling
body: In forest law. The hox-ing or hock-sinewing of dogs; an old mode of laming or disabling dogs. Termes de la Ley

title: Hamesecken
body: In Scotch law. The violent entering into a man’s house without license or against the peace, and the seeking and assaulting him there. Skene de Verb. Sign.; 2 Forb. Inst. 139

title: Hamfare
body: (Sax. From ham, a house.) In Saxon law. An assault made in a house; a breach of the peace in a private house

title: Hamlet
body: A small village; a part or member of a vlll. It is the dlmlnudve of “/tarn,” a vlllage. Cowell. See Rex. v. Mor-ris, 4 Term, 552

title: Hamma
body: A close joining to a house; a croft; a little meadow. Cowell

title: Hammer
body: Metaphorically, a forced sale or sale at public auction. “To bring to the hammer,” to put up for sale at auction. “Sold under the hammer,” sold by an oflicer of the law or by an auctioneer

title: Hamsocne
body: In Saxon law. The right of security nnd privacy in a man’s house. Du Cange. The breach of this privilege by a forcible entry of a house is breach of the peace. Du Cange

title: Hanaper
body: A hamper or basket in which were kept the writs of the court of chaucery relating to the business of a subject, and their returns. 8 Bl. Comm. 49. According to others, the fees accruing on writs, etc., were there kept. Spelman; Du Cange

title: Hand
body: A measure of length equal to four inches, used in measuring the height ot horses. A person's signature

title: Hand Down
body: An appellate court is sold to “haud down" Its decislon in a . case, when the opinion is prepared and filed for transmission to the court below

title: Hand-Fasting
body: In old Engllsh law. Betrothment

title: Hand-Grith
body: In old Engllsh law. Peace or protection given by the king with his own hand

title: Hand Money
body: Money paid in hand to bind a bargaln; earnest money

title: Handbill
body: A written or printed no-tlce dlsplayed to lnform those concerned of something to be done. People v. McLaughlin, 33 Misc. Rep. 691, 68 N. Y. Supp. 1106

title: Handborow
body: In Saxon law. A hand pledge; a name given to the nlne pledges in a decennary or frlborg; the tenth or chief, being called “headborow” (q. v.) So called as being an inferior pledge to the chief. Spelman

title: Handhabend
body: In Saxon law. one having a thing in his hand; that is, a thief found having the stolen goods in his posses* sion. Jurisdictlon to try such thief

title: Handsale
body: Anciently, among all tbe northern nations, shaking of hands was held necessary to blnd a bargain,—a custom stlll retained in verbal contracts. A sale thus made was’ called “handsale," (venditio per mufuam manum complexioncm.) In pro* cess of tlme the same word was used to slg-nlfy the prlce or earnest which was given immediately after the shaking of hands, or lnstead thereof. 2 Bl. Comm. 448

title: Handsel
body: Handsale, or earnest money

title: Handwriting
body: The chirography of a person; the cast or form of writlng pecul-lar to a person, including the size, shape, and style of letters, trlcks of penmanship, nnd whatever gives lndlvlduality to hls writing, distinguishing it from that of other persons. In re Hyland’s will (Surr. Ct.) 27 N. Y. Supp. 963

title: Hang
body: In old practice. To remain undetermined. 'Tt has hung long enough; it is time it were made an end of." Holt, C. J.. 1 Show. 77

title: Hanging
body: In criminal law. Suspen-sion by the neck; the mode of capital pun-ishment nsed in England from time immemorial, and generally adopted in the United States. 4 Bl. Comm. 403

title: Hangman
body: An executioner. One who executes condemned criminals by hanging

title: Hangwite
body: In Saxon law. A fine for Illegal hanging of a thief, or for allowing him to escape. Immunity from such fine. Du Conge

title: Hanse
body: An alliance or confederation among merchants or cities, for the good ordering and protection of the commerce of its members. An Imposition upon merchandise. Du Cange

title: Hansgrave
body: The chief of a company; the head man of a corporation

title: Hantelod
body: In old European lnw. An arrest or attachment. Spelman

title: Happiness
body: SS. The constitutional right of men to pursue their “happiness” means the right to pursue any lawful business or vocation, in any manner not inconsistent wlth the equal rights of others, which may Increase their prosperity, or develop thelr faculties, so as to give to them their highest enjoyment. Butchers’ Union Co. v. Crescent City Co., Ill U. S. 757, 4 Sup. CL 652, 28 L. Ed. 585; 1 Bl. Comm. 41. And see Eng-llsh v: English, 32 N. J. Eq. 750

title: Hague
body: In old statutes. A hand-gun, about three-quarters of a yard long

title: Haracium
body: In old English law. A race of horses and mares kept for breed; a stud. Spelman

title: Harbinger
body: In England, an officer of the royal household

title: Hard Labor
body: A punlshment, addi-tional to mere imprisonment, sometimes im-posed upon convicts sentenced to a penitentiary. But the labor is not, as a rule, any harder than ordinary mechanical labor. Brown v. State, 74 Ala. 483

title: Hard Money
body: Lawful coined money. Henry v. Bank of Salina, 5 HUI (N. Y.) 523,' 536

title: Hardheidis
body: In old Scotch law. Lions; coins formerly of the value of three half-pence. 1 Pitc. Crim. Tr. pt. 1, p. 64, note

title: Hardship
body: The severity with which a proposed construction of the law would bear upon a particular case, founding, sometimes, au argument against such construction, which is otherwise termed the “argument ab inconvenienti

title: Harmless Error
body: See Ebbob

title: Harnasca
body: In old European law. The defensive armor of a man; harness. Spelman

title: Harness
body: All warlike instruments; also the tackle or furniture of a ship

title: Haro, Harron
body: Fr. In Norman and early English law. An outcry, or hue and cry after felons and malefactors. Cowell

title: Harriott
body: The old form of “herlot," (q. v.) williams, Seis. 203

title: Hart
body: A stag or male deer of the forest five years old complete

title: Hasp And Staple
body: In old Scotch law. Tlie form of entering an helr in a sub-ject situated within a royal borough. It consisted of the heir's taking hold of the hasp and staple of the door, (which was the symbol of possession,) with other formalities. Bell; Burrill

title: Haspa
body: In old English law. The hasp of a door; by which livery of eelsin might anciently he made, where there was a house on the premises

title: Hat Money
body: In maritime law. Prl-mage; a small duty pald to the captain and mariners of a shlp

title: Hauber
body: O. Fr. A high lord; a great baron. Spelman

title: Howgh
body: or HOWGH. A green plot in a valley

title: Haul
body: The use of thls word, instead of the statutory word “carry,” in an indictment charging that the defendant “did felo-niously steal, take, and haul away” certain personalty, will not render* the indlctment bad, the words being in one sense equiva-lent. Spittorff v. Stnte, 108 Ind. 171, 8 N. E. 911

title: Haur
body: In old English law. Hatred. Leg. wm. I. c. 16; Blount

title: Haustus
body: Lat. In the clvll law. A species of servitude, consisting In the rlght to draw water from another’s well or spring, in which the iter, (right of way to the well or spring,) so fnr as it is necessary, is tacitly included. Dlg. 8, 3, 1; Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 318

title: Haut Chemin
body: L. Fr. Highway. Yearb. M. 4 Hen. VI. 4

title: Haut Estret
body: L. Fr. High street; highway. Yearb. P. 11 Hen. VI. 2

title: Hauthoner
body: In old English law. A man armed wlth a coat of maii. Jacob

title: Have
body: To possess corporally. “No one, at common law, was sald to have or to be in possession of land, unless it were con-veyed to him by the livery of seisin, which gave him the corporal investiture and bodily occupation thereof." Bl. Law Tracts, 113

title: Haven
body: A place of a large recelpt and safe riding of shlps, so situate and secured by the land circumjacent that the vessels thereby rlde and anchor safely, and are protected hy the adjacent land from dangerous or violent winds; as Milford Haven, Plym-outh Haven, and the like. Hale de Jure Mar. par. 2, c. 2. And see Lowndes v. Board of Trustees, 153 U. S. 1, 14 Sup. Ct. 758, 38 L. Ed. 615; De Longuemere v. New York Ins. Co., 10 Johns. (N. Y.) 125(a); De Lovio v. Bolt, 7 Fed. Cas. 429

title: Hawberk
body: A coat or shirt of mail; hence, derivatively (in feudal law) one who held a fief on the duty or service of providing himself with such armor and standing ready, thus equipped, for military service when called on. wharton

title: Hawgh, Howgh
body: In old English law. A valley. Co. Litt. 5b

title: Hawker
body: A trader who goes from place to place, or along the streets of a town, selling the goods which he carries with him

title: Hay-Bote
body: Another name for “hedge-bote,” being one of the estovers allowed to a tenant for life or years, namely, material for repairing the necessary hedges or fences of his grounds. 2 Bl. Comm. 35; 1 washb. Real Prop. 129

title: Hayward
body: In old English law. An oflicer appointed in the lord's court to keep

title: Hazard.- I
body: In old Englisb law. An

title: Hazardous
body: Exposed to or involving danger; perilous; risky

title: Head
body: Chief; leading; principal; the upper part or priucipal source of a stream

title: Headborough
body: In Saxon law. Tbe head or chlef officer of a borough; chief of the frankpledge tithing or decennary. This office was afterwards, when the petty con-stableship was created, united with that of-flce

title: Head-Courtb
body: Certain tribunals in Scotland, abolished by 20 Geo. II. c. 50. Ersk. 1, 4, 5

title: Headland
body: In old English law. A narrow piece of unplowed land left at the end of a plowed field for the turning of the plow. Called, also, “butt”

title: Head-Note
body: A syllabus to a reported case; a summary of the points decided in the case, which is placed at the head or be-glnning of the report

title: Head-Pence
body: An exaction of 40d. ob more, collected by the sheriff of Northum-berland from the people of that county twice iu every seven years, without account to the king. Abolished in 1444. Cowell

title: Headright Certificate
body: In the

title: Heafodweard
body: In old English law. one of the services to be rendered by a thane, but in what it consisted seems un-certain

title: Healgemote
body: In Saxon law. A court-baron; an ecclesiastical court

title: Heals Fang
body: In Saxon law. A sort of pillory, by which the head of the culprlt was caught between two boards, as feet are caught in a pair of stocks. Cowell

title: Healing Act
body: Another name for a curative act or statute. See Lockhart v. Troy, 48 Ala. 584

title: Health
body: Freedom from slckness or suffering. The right to the enjoyment of health is a subdivision of the right of per-sonal security, one of the absolute rights of persons. 1 Bl. Comm. 129, 134. As to in-juries affecting health, see 3 Bl. Comm. 122

title: Healthy
body: Free from disease or bodily ailment, or any state of the system pecu-liarly susceptible or liable to disease or bod,^ ily ailment Bell v. Jeffreys, 35 N. C. 356. w

title: Hearing
body: In equity praotioe. The

title: Hearsay
body: A term applied to that spe-cies of testimony given by a witness who relates, not what he knows personally, but what others have told him, or what he has heard said by others. Hopt v. Utah, 110 U. S. 574, 4 Sup. Ct 202. 28 L. Ed. 262; Morell v. Morell, 157 Ind. 179, CO N. E. 1092; Stockton v. williams, 1 Doug. (Mich.) 570; People v. Kraft, 91 Hun, 474, 36 N. Y. Supp. 1034

title: Hearth Money
body: A tax levied In England by St. 14 Car. II. c. 10. consisting of two shillings on every hearth or stove in the kingdom. It was extremely unpopular, and wns abollshed by 1 W. & M. St. 1, c

title: Hearth Silver
body: In English law. A species of modus or composition for tithes. Anstr. 323. 326

title: Heat Of Passion
body: In criminal law. A state of violent and uucoutrollable rage

title: Heave To
body: In maritime parlance and admiralty law. To stop a sailing vessel’s headway by bringing her head “into the wind,” that is, in the direction from which the wind blows. A steamer is said to be “hove to" when held In such a position that she takes the heaviest seas upon her quar-ter. The Hugo (D. C.) 57 Fed. 411

title: Hebberman
body: An unlawful fisher in the Thames below London bridge; so called because they generally fished at ebbing tide or water. 4 Hen. VII. c. 15; Jacob

title: Hebberthef
body: In Saxon law. The privilege of having the goods of a thief, and the trial of him, within a certain liberty. Cowell

title: Herring-Wears
body: A device for catch-ing fish in ebbing water. St. 23 Hen. VIII. c. 5

title: Hebdomadius
body: A week's man; the canon or prebendary in a cathedral church, who had the peculiar care of the choir and the offices of it for his own week. Cowell

title: Hecoagium
body: In fendal law. Rent

title: Heck
body: Ah engine to take fish in the river Ouse. 23 Hen. VIII. c. 18

title: Heda
body: A small haven, wharf, or land-ing place

title: Hedagium
body: Toil or customary dues at the hithe or wharf, for landing goods, etc., from which exemption was granted by the crown to some particular persons and societies, wharton

title: Hedge-Bote
body: An allowance of wood for repairing hedges or fences, w’hich a ten-ant or lessee has a right to take off the land let or demised to him. 2 Bl. Comm. 35

title: Hedge-Priest
body: A vagabond priest in olden time

title: Hegemony
body: The leadership of one among several Independent confederate states

title: Hegira
body: The epoch or account of time used by the Arabians and the Turks, who begin their computation from the day that Mahomet was compelled to escape from

title: Hegumenos
body: The leader of the monks in the Greek Church

title: Heifer
body: A young cow which has not had a calf. 2 East, P. C. 616. And see State v. McMinn, 34 Ark. 162; Mundell v. Hammond, 40 Vt. 645

title: Heir
body: At common law. A person who succeeds, by the rules of law, to an estate in lands, tenements, or hereditaments, upon the death of his ancestor, by descent and right of relationship. Hoover v. Smith, 96 Md. 393, 54 Atl. 102; Fletcher v. Holmes, 32 Ind. 510; Sewall v. Roberts, 115 Mass. 268; Dodge’s Appeal, 106 Pa. 216, 51 Am. Rep. 519; Howell v. Gifford, 64 N. J. Eq. 180, 53 Atl. 1074

title: Heir-Looms
body: Such goods and chat-tels as, contrary to the nature of chattels, shall go hy special custom to the heir along with the inheritance, and not to the ex-ecutor. The termination “loom" (Sax.) sig-niflee a limb or member; so that an heir-loom is nothlng else but a limb or member of the inheritance. They are generally such thlngs as cannot be taken away wlthout damaging or dismembering the freehold; such as deer in a park, doves in a cote, deeds and charters, etc. 2 Bl. Comm. 427

title: Heirdom
body: Succession by inheritance

title: Heiress
body: SS. A female heir to a person havlng an estate of lnherltance. when there are more than one, they are called “co-heir-esses," or “co-heirs.”

title: Heirs
body: A word used in deeds of conveyance, (either solely, or in connection with others,) where it is intended to pass a fee

title: Heirshif
body: The quality or condition of being heir, or the relation between the heir and hls ancestor

title: Heirship Movables
body: In Scotch law. The movables which go to the heir, and not to the executor, that the land may not go to the heir completely dismantled, such as the best of furniture, horses, cows, etc., but not funglhles. Bell

title: Hell
body: The name formerly given to a place under the exchequer chamber, where the klng’s debtors were confined. Rich. Dict

title: Helm
body: Thatch or straw; a covering for the head in war; a coat of arms bearing a crest; the tiller or haudle of the rudder of a ship

title: Helowe-Wall
body: The end-wall covering and defendlng the rest of the building. Paroch. Antiq. 573

title: Helsxng
body: A Saxon brass coin, of the value of a half-penny

title: Hemiplegia
body: In medical Juriepru-dence. Unilateral paralysis; paralysis of one slde of the body, commonly due to a lesion in the brain, but sometimes originating from the spinal cord, as in “Brown-Sequard’s paral-ysls,” unilateral paralysis with crossed anaesthesia. In the cerebral form, the Aemi-plegia is sometimes “alternate” or crossed, that is, occurring on the opposite side of the body from the initial lesion

title: Helmelborch
body: or HELMELBORCH

title: Henceforth
body: A word of futurity, whlch, as employed in legal documents, stat-utes, and the llke, always imports a con-tinuity of action or condition from the pres-ent time forward, hut excludes all the past Thomson v. American Surety Co., 170 N. Y. 109, 62 N. E. 1073; opinion of Chief Justice, 7 Pick. (Mass.) 128, note

title: Henchman
body: A page; an attendant; a herald. See Barnes v. State, 88 Md. 347, 41 Atl. 781

title: Hen Edfenny
body: A customary payment of money Instead of hens at Christmas; a composition for eggs. CowelJ

title: Henfare
body: A fine for flight on account of murder. Domesday Book

title: Henghen
body: In Saxon law. A prison, a gaol, or house of correction

title: Hengwyte
body: Sax. In old Engllsh law. An acquittance from a flne for hanglng a thief. Fleta, llb. 1, c. 47, | 17

title: Henrious Vetus
body: Henry the old, or*Elder. Klng Henry I. is so called in anclent English chronicles and charters, to dis-tinguish hlm from the subsequent kings of that name. Spelman

title: Heordpenny
body: Peter-pence, (q. «

title: Heordwerch
body: In Saxon law. The servlce of herdsmen, done at the will of their lord

title: Heptarchy
body: A government exercised by seven persons, or a natlon divided into seven governments. In the year 560, seven dlfferent monarchies had been formed in England by the German tribes, namely, that of Kent by the Jutes; those of Sussex, wes-sex, and Essex by the Saxons; and those of East Anglia, Bernlcia, and Deira by the An-gles. To these were added, about the year 586, an eighth, called the “Kingdom of Mer-cla,” also founded hy the Angles, nnd com-prehendlng nearly the whole of the heart of the kingdom. These states formed what has been designated the “Anglo-Saxon octarchy,” • or more commonly, though not so correctly, the “Anglo-Saxon Heptarchy," from the cus-tom of speaking of Delra and Bernicia under the single appellation of the “Kingdom of Northumberland." wharton

title: Herald
body: In ancient law, a herald was a diplomatic messenger tvho carried messages between kings or states, and especially proc-lamatlons of war, peace, or truce. In English law, a herald is an ofiicer whose duty is to keep genealogical lists and tables, ad-Just armorial bearings, and regulate the cer-emonies at royal coronations and funerals

title: Heraldry
body: The art, office, or science of heralds. Also an old and obsolete abuse of buying and selling precedence in the pa-per of causes for hearing

title: Herbage
body: In English law. An ease-ment or liberty, which consists in the right to pasture cattle on another’s ground

title: Herbagium Anterius
body: The first crop of grass or hay, in opposition to after-math or second cutting. Paroch. Antiq. 459

title: Harbinger
body: or HARBINGER. An

title: Herbergagium
body: Lodgings to receive guests in the way of hospitality. CoweU

title: Herbergatus
body: Harbored or enter-talned in an lnn. Cowell

title: Herbury
body: or HERBURY. An lnn

title: Hercia
body: A harrow. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 77

title: Herciare
body: To harrow. 4 Inst. 270

title: Herciatura
body: In old English law. Harrowing; work with a harrow. Fleta, llb. 2, c. 82, $ 2

title: Herciscunda
body: In the clvll law. To *be divided. Familia hcrcixcundo, an inherlt-ance to be divided. Actio famili# herds-fund#, an action for dividing an inheritance. Erciscunda is more commonly used in the civil law. Dig. 10, 2; InsL 3, 28, 4; Id. 4, 6, 20

title: Herdewich
body: A grange or place for cattle or husbandry. Mon. Angl. pt 3

title: Herdwerch, Heordwerch
body: Herdsmen’s work, or customary labor, done by shepherds and lnferior tenants, at the will of the lord. CowelL

title: Hereafter
body: A word of futurity, always used in statutes aud legal documents ss indicative of future time, excluding both the present and the past Chapman v. Holmes, 10 N. J. Law, 26; Tremont & S. Mills v. Lowell, 165 Mass. 265, 42 N. E. 1134; Dobbins v. Cragin, 50 N. J. Eq. 640, 23 AU. 172; Thomas v. Mueller, 106 IU. 43

title: Herebannum
body: In old English law. A proclamation summoning the army into the field

title: Herebote
body: The royal edict summoning the people to the field. CowelL

title: Heredad
body: In Spanlsh law. A piece of land under cultivatlon; a cultivated farm, real estate; an inheritance or heirship. —Heredad yaoente. From Lat. “hareditas jacens,” (q. v.) In Spanish law. An inhere itance not yet entered upon or appropriated, white, New Recop. b. 2. tit. 19. c. 2, f

title: Heredero
body: In Spanish law. Heir; he who, by legal or testamentary disposition, succeeds to the property of a deceased person. “Deeres censeatur cum defuncto uno eademque persona” Las Partidas, 7, 9, 13; See Emeric v. Alvarado, 64 Cal. 529, 2 Pac. 433

title: Hereditagium
body: In Sicilian and Neapolitan law. That whlch is held by heredi-tary right; the same with hercditamentum (hereditament) in English law. Spelman

title: Hereditaments
body: Things capable of being inherited, he it corporeal or incorpo-real. real, personal, or mixed, and inclnding not only lands and everything thereon, but also heir-looms, nnd certain furniture which, by custom, mny descend to the heir together with the land. Co. Litt. 5b; 2 Bl. Comm. 17; Neills v. Munson, 108 N. Y. 453. 35 N. E. 739; owens v. Lewis, 46 Ind. 508, 15 Am. Rep. 295; whltlock v. Greacen, 48 N. J. Eq. 359, 21 Atl. 944 ; Mitchell v. warner, 5 Conn. 497; New York v. Mabie, 13 N. Y. 159, 64 Ain. Dec. 538

title: Hereditary
body: That which is the sub

title: Herefare
body: Sax. A going into or with an army; a going out to war, (profcctio militaris;) an expedition. Spelman

title: Heregeat
body: A heriot, (q. v

title: Heregeld
body: Sax. In old English law. A tribute or tax levied for the maintenance of an army. Spelman

title: Heremitorium
body: A place of retlre-ment for hermits. Mon. Angl. tom. 3, p. 18

title: Heremones
body: Followers of nn army

title: Herenach
body: An archdeacon. Cowell

title: Heres
body: Heir; an heir. A form of haeres. very common in the civil law. See HjEBES

title: Hereslita, Heressa, Heressiz
body: A hired soldier who departs withont license. 4 Inst 128.

title: Heresy
body: In English law. An offense against religion, consisting not in a total de-nlal of Christianity, but of some of its essen-tlal doctrines, publicly and obstinately avow-ed. 4 Bl. Comm. 44, 45. An opinion on dlvlne subjects devised by human reason, openly taught, and obstinately maintained

title: Heretooh
body: A general, leader, or commander; also a baron of the realm. Dn Fresne

title: Heretofore
body: This word simply de-notes time past, in distinction from time present or time future, and has no definite and precise signification beyond this. Andrews v. Thayer, 40 Conn. 157

title: Heretum
body: In old records. A court or yard for drawing up guards or mllitary retinue. Cowell

title: Herezeld
body: In Scotch law. A glft or present made or left by a tenant to his lord as a token of reverence. Skene

title: Herge
body: In Saxon law. offenders who joined in a body of more than thirty-five to commit- depredations

title: Herigalds
body: In old Engllsh law. A sort of garment. Cowell

title: Heriot
body: In English'law. A customary tribute of goods and chattels, payable to the lord of the fee on the decease of the owner of the land

title: Herischild
body: In old Engllsh law. A species of mllitary servlce, or knlght'a fee. Cowell

title: Herischulda
body: In old Scotch law. A flue or penalty for not obeying the proclaina-tion made for warfare. Skene

title: Herisoindium
body: A division of household goods. Blonnt

title: Herislit
body: Laying down of arms. Blount Desertion from the army. Spelman

title: Heribtal
body: The station of an army; the place where a camp is pitched. Spelman

title: Heritable
body: Capable of being taken by descent A . term chiefly used In Scotch law, where it enters lnto several phrases

title: Heritage
body: In tbe oivil law. Every species of immovable whlch can be the subject of property; such as lands, houses, orchards, woods, marshes, ponds, etc., in whatever mode they may have been acquired, either by descent or purchase. 3 Toullier, no. 472

title: Heritor
body: In Scotch law. A proprietor of land. 1 Eames, Eq. Pref

title: Hermandad
body: In Spanish law. A fra* ternity formed among different towns and villages to prevent the commission of crimes, and to prevent the abuses and vexations to which they were subjected -by men in power. Bouvier

title: Hermaphrodite
body: In medical juris-prudence. A person of doubtful or double sex; one possessing, really or apparently, and in more or less developed form, some or all of the genltal organs of both sexes

title: Hermeneutics
body: The science or art of construction and Interpretation. By the phrase “legal hermeneutics” is understood the systematic body of rules which are recognlzed as applicable to the construction and lnterpretatlon of legal writings

title: Hermer
body: A great lord. Jacoh

title: Hermogenian Oode
body: See Conn

title: Hernescus
body: A heron. CowelL

title: Hernasium
body: or HERNASIUM

title: Heroud, Heraud
body: L. Fr. A herald

title: Herpex
body: A harrow. Spelman

title: Herpioatio
body: In old Engllsh taw. A day's work wlth a harrow. Spelman

title: Herring Silver
body: Thls was a composition in money for the custom of supplying herrings for the provision of a religious house, wharton

title: Herus
body: Lat. A master. Servus facit ut rterus det, the servant does [the work] in order that the master may glve [hlm the wages agreed on.] Herus dat ut servus facit, the master gives [or agrees to give, the wages,] in consideration of, or with a view to, the servant’s doing [the work.] 2 Bl. Comm. 445

title: Hesia
body: An easement Du Cange

title: Hest Corn
body: In old records. Com or grain glven or devoted to rellglous persons or purposes. 2 Mon. Angl. 367b; CoweU

title: Hestha
body: or HESTHA. A little loaf of bread

title: Hetabrarcha
body: The head of a rellglous house; the head of a college; the ward* en of a corporation

title: Hetjeria
body: In Roman law. A company, society, or college

title: Heuvelborh
body: Sax. In old English law. A surety, (warrantus

title: Heylode
body: In old records. A customary burden upon lnferlor tenants, for mend-lng or repalrlng hays or hedges

title: Heymeotus
body: A hay-net; a net for catching conies. CoweU

title: Hibernagium
body: The season for sowing winter corn. CowelL

title: Hidage
body: An extraordinary tax formerly payable to the crown for every hlde of land. This taxation was levled, not in money, but provlslon of armor, etc. Cowell

title: Hidalgo
body: In Spanlsh law. A noble; a person entltled to the rights of noblllty. By hidalgos are understood men chosen from

title: Hidalguia
body: In Spanish law. Nobility hy descent or lineage, white, New Recop. b. 1, tit 6, c. 8, | 4

title: Hide
body: In old Engllsh law. A measure of land, being as much as could be worked wlth one plow. It is variously estimated at from 60 to 100 acres, but was probably de-termlned by local usage. Another meaning was as much land as would support one family or the dwellers in a mansion-house. Also a house; a dwelling-house

title: Hidel
body: In old English law. A place of protection; a sanctuary. St 1 Hen. VII. cc. 5, 6; CowelL

title: Hidgild
body: A sum of money pald by a villein or servant to save himself from a whipping. Fleta, L 1, c. 47, | 20

title: High
body: This term, as used In various -compound legal phrases, is sometimes merely an addltlon of dignity, not Importing a com-parlson; hut more generally it means exalt-ed, either in rank or location, or occupying a position of superiority, and in a few in-etances it Implies superiority in respect to Importance, size, or frequency or publicity of use, e. g., "high seas," "highway.”

title: Higher And Lower Scale
body: In

title: Highness
body: A title of honor given to princes. The kings of England, before the time of James I., were not usually salated with the title of “Majesty," but wlth that of “Highness.” The children of crowned heads generally recelve the style of "Highness." wharton

title: Highway
body: A free and pnblic road, way, or street; one which every person has the right to use. Abbott v. Duluth (C. C.) 104 Fed. 837; Shelby County Com’rs v. Cas-tetter, 7 Ind. App. 309, 83 N. B. 986; State v. Cowan, 29 N. C. 248; In re City of New York, 135 N. Y. 253, 31 N. B. 1043, 81 Am. St Rep. 825; Parsons v. San Francisco, 23 Cal. 464

title: Highwayman
body: A bandit; one who robs travelers upon the highway

title: Higler
body: In English law. A hawker or peddler. A person who carries from door to door, and sells hy retail, small articles of provisions, and the like

title: Higuela
body: In Spanish law. A receipt given by an heir of a decedent, setting forth what property he has received from the estate

title: Hilary Rules
body: A collection of orders and forms extensively modifying the plead-ing and practice in the English superior courts of common law, established in Hilary term, 1834. Stimson

title: Hilary Term
body: In English law. A term of court, beglning on the 11th and ending on tbe 31st of January in each year. Superseded (1875) by Hilary sittings, which begin January 11th, and end on the wednes-day before Easter

title: Hindeni Homines
body: A society of men. The Saxons ranked men Into three classes, and valued them, as to. satisfaction for ln-jurles, etc., according to their class. The highest class were valued at 1,200s., and were called “twelf hindmcn;" the middle class at 600s., and called “ttexhindmen the lowest at 200s., called “ttryhindmen” Thelr wlves were termed “hindus.” Brompt Leg. Alfred, c. 12

title: Hinder And Delay
body: To hinder and delay is to do something whlch is an attempt to defraud, rather than a successful fraud; to put some obstacle in the path, or interpose some time, unjustifiably, before the creditor can reallze what is owed out of his debtor’s property. See Walker v. Sayers, 5 Bush (Ky.) 5S2; Burdick v. Post, 12 Barb. (N. Y.) 186; Crow v. Beardsley, 68 Mo. 439; Burn-ham v. Brennan, 42 N. ¥. Super. Ct. 63

title: Hindu Law
body: The system of native law prevailing among the Gentoos, nnd admlnis-tered by the government of British Indla

title: Hind
body: or HIND. In old English law. A husbandry servant

title: Hinefare
body: In old English law. The loss or departure of a servant from his master. Domesday

title: Hipoteca
body: In Spanish law. A mortgage of real property

title: Hirciscunda
body: See Hcbciscunda

title: Hirer

title: Hiring

Code Ga. 1882, | 2085

title: Hirst, Hurst
body: In old English law

title: His Excellency
body: In English law

title: His Honor

title: His Testibus

title: Hitherto

title: Hiwiso
body: In old English law. A hide of land

title: Hlaf Jeta
body: Sax. A servant fed at his master’s cost

title: Hlaford

title: Hlafordsocna
body: Sax. A lord’s protection. Du Cange

title: Hlafordswice
body: Sax. In Saxon law. The crime of betraying one's lord, (proditio domini;) treason. Crabb, Eng. Law, 59, 301

title: Hlasocna
body: Sax. The benefit of the law. Du Cange

title: Hlothbote
body: In Saxon law. A fine for being present at an unlawful assembly. Spelman

title: Hlothe
body: In Saxon law. An unlawful assembly from eight to thirty-five, inclusive. Cowell

title: Hoastmen
body: In Engllsh law. An ancient gild or fraternity at Newcastle-upon-Tyne, who dealt in sea coal. St. 21 Jac. L c. 3

title: Hobbit

title: Hobblers

title: Hoo Quidem Perquam Durum Est, Sed Ita Lex Scripta Est
body: Let. (This Indeed is exceedingly hard, bat so the law is written; such is the written or positive law.) An observation quoted by Blackstone as used by Ulplan in the civil law; and applied to cases where courts of equlty have no power to abate the rigor of the law. Dig. 40, 9, 12, 1; 3 Bl. Comm. 430

title: Hoc Paratus Est Verifioare
body: Lat This he is ready to verify.

title: Hoccus Saltis
body: A hoke, hole, or less-er pit of salt. Cowell

title: Hock-Tuesday Money
body: This was a duty given to the landlord that his tenants and bondmen might solemnize the day on which the English conquered the Danes, being the second Tuesday after Easter week. Cowell

title: Hodge-Podge Act
body: A name applled to a statute which comprises a medley of incongruous subjects

title: Hoga
body: In old English law. A hill or mountain. In old English, a how. Qrene hoga, Grenehow. Domesday; Spelman

title: Hogaster
body: In old English law. A sheep of the second year. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 79, §§ 4, 12. A young hog. Cowell

title: Hogietus
body: or HOGIETU8. A hog or

title: Hoghenhyne
body: In Saxon law. A house-servant. Any stranger who lodged three nlghts or more at a man’s house in a decennary was called “hoghenhyne,” and hls host became responsible for his acts as for those of his servant

title: Hogshead
body: A measure of a capacity containing the fourth part of a tun, or sixty-three gallons. Cowell. A large cask, of indefinlte contents, but usually containing from one hundred to one hundred and forty gallons, webster

title: Holder
body: The holder of a bill of exchange, promissory note, or check is the person who bas legally acquired the possession of the same, from a person capable of trans-ferring it, by indorsement or delivery, and who is entitled to receive payment of the instrument from the party or parties liable to meet it. Bowling v. Harrison, 6 How. 258, 12 L. Ed. 425; Crocker-woolworth Nat. Bank v. Nevada Bank, 139 Cal. 564, 73 Pac. 456, 63 L. R. A. 245, 96 Am. St. Rep. 169; Rlce v. Hogan, 8 Dana (Ky.) 135; Rev. Laws Mass. 1902, p. 053. $ 207

title: Holdes
body: Sax. In Saxon law. A mll-ltary commander. Spelman

title: Holding
body: In English law. A piece of land held under a lease or slmllar tenancy for agricultural, pastoral, or slmllar pur-poses

title: Holiday
body: A religious festival; a day set apart for commemorating some important event in history; a day of exemption from labor. Webster. A day upon which the usual operations of business are suspended and the courts closed, and, generally, no legal process is served

title: Holm
body: An Island in a river or the sea. Spelman

title: Holografo
body: In Spanish law. A holograph. An Instrument (particularly a will) wholly in the handwriting of the person executing it; or which, to be valid, must be so wrltten by hls own hand

title: Holograph
body: A will or deed written entirely by the testator or grantor with hls own hand. Estate of Billings, 64 Cal. 427, 1 Pac. 701; Harrison v. weatherby, 180 111. 418, 64 N. E. 237

title: Holt
body: Sax. In old English law. A wood or grove. Spelman; Cowell; Co. Litt. 4b

title: Holy Orders
body: In eccleslastlcal law. The orders of bishops, (Including archbish-ops,) priests, and deacons in the Church of England. The Roman canonists had the or-ders of bishop, (in which the pope and arch-bishops were included,) prlest, deacon, sub-deacon, psalmist, acolyte, exorcist, reader, ostiarius. 3 Stepb. Comm. 55, and note a

title: Homage
body: In feudal law. A service (or the ceremony of rendering it) which a tenant was bound to perform to his lord on receiving investiture of a fee, or succeeding to it as heir, in acknowledgment of the ten-ure. It is described by Littleton as thc most honorable service of reverence that a free tenant might do to his lord. The ceremony was as follows: The tenant, heing ungirt and wlth hare head, knelt before the lord

title: Homager
body: one who does or is bound to do homage. Cowell

title: Homagio Respectuando
body: A wrlt to the escheator commanding him to de-liver seisin of lands to the heir of the king's tenant, notwithstanding his homage not done. Fitzh. Nat. Brev. 269

title: Homagium
body: L. Lat. Homage, (q. v

title: Hombre Bueno
body: In Spanlsh law. The judge of a district Also an arbitrator chosen by the parties to a suit Also a man in good standing; one who is competent to testify in a suit

title: Home
body: when a person voluntarily takes up his abode in a given place, with intention to remain permanently, or for an indefinite period of time, or without any present inten-tion to remove therefrom, such place of abode becomes hls residence or home. This word has not the same technical meaning as “domicile." See isnghammer v. Munter, 80 Md. 518, 31 Atl. 300, 27 L. R. A. 330; King v. King, 155 Mo. 406, 56 S. W. 534; Dean v. Cannon, 37 W. Va. 123, 16 S. H 444; Jef-ferson v. washington, 19 Me. 293; welch v. whelpley, 62 Mich. 15, 28 N. W. 744, 4 Am. St. Rep. 810; warren v. Thomaston, 43 Me. 418, 69 Am. Dec. 69

title: Homme
body: or HOMME. L. Fr. Man; a man

title: Homesoken, Homsoken
body: See

title: Homestall
body: A mansion-house. Dlck-inson v. Mayer, 11 Heisk. (Tenn.) 521

title: Homestead
body: The home place; the place where the home is. It is the home, the

title: Homicidal
body: Pertaining to homicide; relating to homicide; impelling to homicide; as a homicidal mania. (See Insanity

title: Homicide
body: The killing of any human creature. 4 Bl. Comm. 177. The killing of one human being by the act, procurement, or omission of another. Pen. Code N. Y. 8 179. The act of a human being In taking away tbe

title: Homicidium
body: Lat Homicide, (q. v

title: Hominatio
body: The mustering of men; the doing of homage

title: Homine Capto In Withernam-Ium
body: A writ to take him that had taken any bond man or woman, and led him or her out of the country, so that he or she could not be replevied accordlng to law. Reg. orig. 79

title: Homine Eligendo
body: In old English law. A writ directed to a corporation, re-qulring the members to make choice of a man to keep one part of the seal appointed for statutes merchant, when a former is dead, according to the statute of Acton Burnell. Reg. orig. 178; wharton

title: Homine Replegiando
body: In English law. A writ which lay to replevy a man out of prison, or out of the custody of any private person, in the same manner that chat-tels taken in distress may he replevied. Brown

title: Homines
body: Lat. In feudal law. Men; feudatory tenants who claimed a privilege of having their causes, etc., tried only in their lord’s court. Paroch. Antiq. 15

title: Homiplagium
body: In old English law. The maiming of a man. Blount

title: Homme
body: Fr. Man; a man. This term is defined by the Civil Code of Louisiana to include a woman. Article 3522, notes 1, 2

title: Hommes De Fief
body: Fr. In feudal law. Men of the fief; feudal tenants; the peers in the lords’ courts. Montesq., Esprlt des Lois, liv. 28, c. 27

title: Hommes Feodaux
body: Fr. In feudal law. Fendal tenants; the same with horn

title: Homo
body: Lat. A man; a human being, male or female; a vassal, or feudal tenant; a retainer, dependent, or servant

title: Homologacion
body: In Spanish law. The tacit consent and approval inferred by law from the omission of the parties, for the space of ten days, to complain of the sen-tences of arbitrators, appointment of syndics, or assignees of insolvents, settlements of successions, etc. Also the approval given by the judge of certain acts and agreements for the purpose of rendering them more bind-ing and executory. Escrlche

title: Homologare
body: In the civil law. To confirm or approve; to consent or assent; to confess. Calvin

title: Homologate
body: In modern civil law. To approve; to confirm; as a court homologates a proceeding. See Homologation. Literally, to use the same words with an-other; to say the like. Viales v. Gnrdenler, 9 Mart. O. S. (La.) 324. To assent to what another says or writes

title: Homologation
body: In the oivil law

title: Homonymie
body: A term applied in the civU law to cases where a law was repeated, or laid down in the same terms or to the Bame effect, more than once. Cases of Iter* ation and repetition. 2 Kent, Comm. 489, note

title: Hondhabend
body: Sax. Having in hand. See Handiiabend

title: Honeste Vtvere
body: Lat To live hon-orably, creditably, or vlrtuously. one of the three general precepts to whlch Justinian reduced the whole doctrine of the law, (InsL 1, 1, 3; Bract, fols. 3, 3b,) the others being alterum non Ice der e, (not to injure others,) and suum euique tribuere, (to render to every man his due

title: Honestus
body: Lat. of good character or standing. Coram duobus vel pluribus viris legalibus ct honestis, before two or more lawful and good men. Bract fol. 6L

title: Honorable
body: A title of courtesy glv-en in England to the younger children of

title: Honorarium
body: In the civil law. An honorary or free gift; a gratuitous payment, as distinguished from hire or compensation for service; a lawyer’s or counsellor's fee. Dig. 50, 13, 1, 10-12

title: Honorarium Jus
body: Lat in Roman law. The law of the prstors and the edicts of the sediles

title: Honorary
body: As applied to public offices and other positions of responsibility or trust, this term means either that the office or tltle is bestowed upon the Incumbent as a mark of honor or compliment, without Intending to charge him with the active discharge of the duties of the place, or else that he is to re-cel ve no salary or other compensation in money, the honor conferred by the Incumbency of the office being his only reward. See B os-well v. New York, 81 N. Y. 258. In other connections, it means attached to or grew-lng out of some honor or dignity or honorable ofiice, or else it imports an obligation or duty growing out of honor or trust only, ss distinguished from legal accountability

title: Honoris Respectum
body: By reason of honor or privilege. See Challenge

title: Hontfongenethef
body: In Saxon law. a thief taken with hondhabend; i. e„ hav-Ing the thing stolen in his hand. CowelL

title: Hony
body: L. Fr. Shame; evil; disgrace. Hony soit qui mal y pense, evil be to him who evil thinks

title: Hookland
body: Land plowed and sown every year

title: Hopoon
body: In old English law. A valley. CowelL

title: Hoppo
body: A Chinese term for a collector; an overseer of commerce

title: Hora
body: Lat An hour; the hour

title: Horca
body: In Spanish law. A gallows; the punlshment of hanging, white, New Re-cop. b. 2, tit 19, c. 4, J L

title: Horda
body: In old records. A cow in calf

title: Hordera
body: In old Engllsh law. A treasurer. Du Cange

title: Horderium
body: In old English law. A hoard; a treasure, or repository. Cowell

title: Hordeum
body: In old records. Barley. Hordeum palmale, beer barley, as distin-guished from common barley, which was called “hordeum quadragesimalc." Blount

title: Horn
body: In old Scotch practice. A kind of trumpet used in denouncing contumacious persons rebels and outlaws, which was done with three blasts of the horn by the king’s sergeant. This was called "putting to the hornand the party so denounced was said to be “at the horn.4* Bell. See Hobninq

title: Horn-Book
body: A primer; a book ex-plaining the rudiments of any science or branch of knowledge. The phrase “horn-book law" is a colloquial designation of the rudiments or most familiar principles of law

title: Horn Tenure
body: In old English lnw. Tenure by cornage; that is, by the service of winding a horn when the Scots or other ene-mies entered the land, in order to warn the king’s subjects. This was a species of grnnd serjeanty. Litt. 5 156; 2 Bl. Comm. 74

title: Horngeld
body: Sax. In old English law. A tax withln a forest, paid for horned beasts. CoweU; Blount

title: Horning
body: In Scotch law. “Letters of horning" is the name given to a judicial pro-cess issuing on the decree of a court, by which the debtor is summoned to perform his obligation in terms of the decree, the con-sequence of his failure to do so heing lia-bllity to arrest and imprisonment It was anciently the custom to proclaim a debtor who had failed to obey such process a rebel or outlaw, whlch was done by three blasts of the horn hy the king's sergeant in a public place. Thls was called “putting to the horn,” whence the name

title: Horreum
body: Lat A place for keeping graln; a granary. A place for keeping fruits, wines, and goods generally; a store-house. Calvin.; Bract fol. 48

title: Hobs
body: L. Fr. Out; out of; without

title: Hors Wealh
body: In old English law. The wealh, or Briton who had care of the klng's horses

title: Hobs Weard
body: In old English law. A servlce or corvde, consisting in watchlng the horses of the lord. Anc. Inst Eng

title: Horse
body: An animal of the genus equus and species caballus. In a narrow and strict sense, the term Ib applied only to the male, and only to males of four years old or there-abouts, younger horses being called “colts.” But even in this sense the term Includes both stallions and geldings. In a wider sense, and as generally used in statutes, the word is taken as nomcn gcneralissimum, and in-cludes not only horses strictly so called, but also colts, mares and fillies, and mules and asses. See owens v. State, 38 Tex. 557; Ashworth v. Mounsey, L. R. 9 Exch. 187 ;.Pul-len v. State, 11 Tex. App. 91; Allison ▼. Brookshire, 38 Tex. 201; State v. Ingram, 16 Kan. 19; State v. Dunnavant, 3 Brev. (S. C.) 10, 5 Am. Dec. 530; State v. Gooch, 60 Ark. 218, 23 S. W. 640; Davis v. Collier, 13 Ga. 491. Compare Richardson v. Chicago & A. R. Co.; 149 Mo. 311, 50 8. W. 782

title: Horse Guards
body: The directing power of the military forces of the kingdom of Great Britain. 'Hie commander in chief, or general commanding the forces, is at the

title: Hortus
body: Lat. In the civil law. A gar-den. Dig. 32, 91, 6

title: Hospes
body: Lat A guest 8 Coke, 32

title: Hospes Generalis
body: A great chamberlain

title: Hospital
body: An institution for the re-ception and care of sick, wounded, infirm, or aged persons; generally incorporated, and then of the class of corporations called “elee-mosynary” or “charitable." See In re Curtiss (Sur.) 7 N. Y. Supp. 207

title: Hospitallers
body: The knights of a re-ligious order, so called because they built a hospital at Jerusalem, wherein pilgrims were received. All their lands and goods in Eng-land were given to the sovereign by 32 Hen. VIIL c. 24

title: Hospitator
body: A host or entertainer

title: Hospitia
body: Inns. Hospitia communia, common inns. Reg. orig. 105. Hospitia curia, inns of court Hospitia cancellarics, inns of chancery. Crabb, Eng. Law, 428, 429 ; 4 Reeve, Eng. Law, 120

title: Hospiticide
body: one that kills hls guest or host

title: Hospitium
body: An inn; a household. See Cromwell ▼. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 17

title: Hospodar
body: A Turkish governor in Mol-davia or wallachia

title: Host
body: L. Fr. An army. Britt, c. 22. A military expedition; war. Kelham

title: Hostage
body: A person who is given into the possession of the enemy, in a public war, his freedom (or life) to stand as security for the performance of some contract or promise made by the belligerent power giving the hostage with the other

title: Hostelagium
body: In old records. A right to receive lodging and entertainment, anciently reserved by lords in the houses of tlieir tenants. CowelL

title: Hosteler
body: See Hostler

title: Hostes
body: Lat Enemies. Hostes humanl generis, enemies of the human race; i. e., pirates

title: Hostia
body: In old records. The host-bread, or consecrated wafer, in the eucha-rist Cowell

title: Hosticide
body: One who kills an enemy

title: Hostilaria, Hospitalaria
body: A

title: Hostile
body: Having the character of an enemy; standing in the relation of an ene-my. See 1 Kent, Comm. c. 4

title: Hostility
body: In the law of nations. A state of open war. “At the breaking out of hostility.” 1 Kent, Comm. 60

title: Hostler
body: In Norman and old English law, this was the tltle of the officer in a monastery charged with the entertainment of guests. It was also applied (until about the time of Queen Elizabeth) to an innkeeper, and afterwards, when the keeping of horses at livery becamea distinct occupation, to the keeper of a livery stable, and then (under the modern form “ostler”) to the groom in charge of the stables of an inn. Cromwell v. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 20. In the lan-guage of railroading, an “ostler” or “hostler” at a roundhouse is one whose duty it is to receive locomotives as they come in from the road, care for them in tbe roundhouse, aud have them cleaned and ready for de-parture when wanted. Railroad Co. v. Mas-sig, 50 IU. App. 666; Railroad Co. r. Ash-ling, 34 111. App. 105; Grannis v. Railroad Co., 81 Iowa, 444, 46 N. W. 1067

title: Hot-Water Ordeal
body: In old Eng-lish law. This was a test, in cases of accusation, by hot water; the party accused and suspected being appointed by the judge to put hls arms up to the elbows in seeth

title: Hotchpot
body: The blending and mixing property belonging to different persons, in order to divide it equally. 2 Bl. Comm. 190

title: Hotel
body: An inn; a public house or tavern; a house for entertaining strangers or travelers. St ‘Louis v. Siegrist, 46 Mo. 594; People v. Jones, 54 Barb. (N. Y.) 316; Crom-weii v. Stephens, 2 Daly (N. Y.) 19

title: Hour
body: The twenty-fourth part of a natural day; sixty minutes of time

title: Hour Of Gause
body: In Scotch practice. The hour when a court is met. 3 How. 8tate Tr. 603

title: House
body: 1. A dwelling; a building de-signed for the habitation and residence of men

title: Houseage
body: A fee paid for housing goods by a carrier, or at a wharf, etc

title: Housebreaking
body: In criminal law. Breaking and entering a dwelling-house with Intent to commit any felony therein. If done by night, it comes under the definition of “burglary.”

title: Household
body: A family llvtng together. May v. Smith, 48 Ala. 488; woodward v. Murray, 18 Johns. (N. Y.) 402; Arthur v. Morgan, 112 U. S. 495, 5 Sup. Ct 241, 28 L. Ed. 825. Those who dwell under the same roof and compose a famlly. webster. A man’s family living together constitutes hls household, though he may have gone to another state

title: Householder
body: The occupier of a house. Brande. More correctly, one who keeps house with his family; the head or master of a family, webster; 18 Johns. 302. one who has a household; the head of a household. See Greenwood v. Maddox, 27 Ark. <»55; Sullivan v. Canan, wils. (Ind.) 534; Shively v. Lankford, 174 Mo. 535, 74 S. W. 835

title: Housekeeper
body: one who is in actual possession of and who occupies a house, as

title: Hovel
body: A place used by husbandmen to set thelr plows, carts, and other farming utensils out of the rain and sun. A shed; a cottage; a mean house

title: Howe
body: In old English law. A hllL Co. Lltt 5b

title: Hoyman
body: The master or captain of a hoy

title: Huckster
body: A petty dealer and retailer of small articles of provisions, particularly farm and garden produce. Mays ▼. Cincln-natl, 1 ohlo St 272; Lebanon County v. Kline, 2 Pa. Co. CL R. 622

title: Huousque
body: In old pleading. Hither-to. 2 Mod. 24

title: Hude-Geld
body: ln old English law. An acquittance for an assault upon a trespassing servant. Supposed to be a mistake or mis-print in Fleta for “hinegeld." Fleta, lib. 1, c. 47, | 20. Also the price of one's skin, or the money paid by a servant to save himself from a whipping. Du Cange

title: Hue And Cry
body: In old English law. A ioud outcry with which felons (such as rob-bers, burglars, and murderers) were anciently pursued, and which all who heard it were hound to take up, and join in the pursuit, nntll the malefactor was taken. Bract fols. 115b, 124; 4 BL Comm. 293

title: Huebras
body: In Spanish law. A* meas-ure of land equal to as much as a yoke of oxen can plow in one day. 2 whlte, Recop. (38,) 49; Strother v. Lucas, 12 Pet 443, 0 L. Ed. 1137

title: Huis
body: L. Fr. A door. “Al huis del es-gIise,” at the door of the church. Bendloe, 133

title: Huisserium
body: A ship used to transport horses. Also termed “u/fer.”

title: Huissiers
body: ln French law. Marshals; ushers; process-servers; sheriffs* officers. Ministerial officers attached to the courts, to effect legal servlce of process required by law in actions, to issue executions, etc., and to maintain order during the sitting of the courts

title: Hulka
body: In old records. A hulk or small vessel. CowelL

title: Hullus
body: In old records. A hilL 2 Mon. Angl. 292; Cowell

title: Humagium
body: A moist place. Mon. Angl

title: Hundred
body: Under the Saxon orgauiza-tion of England, each county or shire corn-prised an indefinite number of hundreds, each hundred containing ten titMngs, or groups of ten families of freeholders or frank-pledges. The hundred was governed by a high constable, and had its own conrt; but its most remarkable feature was the corporate responsibility of the whole for the crimes or defaults of the Individual members. The introduction of this plan of or-ganization into England is commonly ascrib-ed to Alfred, but the idea, as well of the collective liability as of the division, was prob-ably known to the ancient German peoples, as we find the 6ame thing established in the Frankish kingdom under Clothaire, and in Denmark. See 1 BL Comm. 115; 4 BL Comm. 411

title: Hundredarius
body: In old English law. A hundredary or hundredor. A name given to the chief officer of a hundred, as weil as to the freeholders who composed it Spel. voc. “H undr edits

title: Hundred Ary
body: The chief or presiding officer of a hundred

title: Hun-Dredes Man
body: DOR, or HUN-DREDES MAN. The presiding officer in the hundred court Anc. Inst Eng

title: Hundredors
body: In English law. The Inhabitants or freeholders of a hundred, an-ciently the suitors or judges of the hundred court Persons impaneled or fit to be lm-paneled upon juries, dwelling wlthln the hundred where the cause of action arose. Cromp. Jur. 217. It was formerly necessary to have some of these upon every panel of jurors. 3 BL Comm.' 859, 360 ; 4 Steph. Comm. 370

title: Hung Jury
body: A jury so irreconcilably divided in opinion that they cannot agree npon any verdict

title: Hurdereferst
body: A domestic; one of a family

title: Hurdle
body: In English criminal law. A kind of sledge, on which convicted felons were drawn to the place of execution.

title: Hurricane
body: A storm of great violence or intensity, of which the particular characteristic is the high velocity of the wind. There is naturally no exact measure to distinguish between an ordinary storm and a hurricane, bnt the wind should reach a velocity of at least 50 or 60 miles an hour to be called by the latter name, or, os expressed in some of the cases, it should be sufficient to “throw down buildings.” A hurricane is properly a circular storm in the nature of a cyclone. See Pelican Ins. Cb. v. Troy Co-op. Ass'n, 77 Tex. 225, 13 S. W. 980; Queen Ins. Co. v. Hudnut Co., 8 Ind. App. 22, 35 N. B. 397; Tyson v. Union Mut Fire A Storm Co., 2 Montg. Co. Law Rep’r (Pa.) 17

title: Hirst
body: HYRST, HERST, or HIRST

title: Hurt
body: In such phrases as “to the hurt or annoyance of another,” or “hurt, molest-ed, or restrained in his person or estate," this word is not restricted to physical in-juries, but Includes also mental pain, as well as discomfort or annoyance. See Row-land v. Miller (Super. N. Y.) 15 N. Y. Supp. 702; Pronk v. Brooklyn Heights R. Co., 68 App. Div. 390, 74 N. T. Supp. 375; Thurston v. whitney, 2 Cush. (Mass.) 110

title: Hortus
body: DUS, or HORTUS. A ram or

title: H U R T O
body: In Spanish law. Theft white. New Recop. b. 2, tit 20

title: Husband
body: A married man; one who has a lawful wlfe living. The correlative of “wife

title: Husbandman
body: A farmer; a cultivator or tiller of the ground. The word “farmer” is colloquially used as synonymous with “hus-bandmnn,” but originally meant a tenant who cultivates leased ground

title: Husbandria
body: In old English law. Husbandry. Dyer, (Fr. Ed.) 35b

title: Husbandry
body: Agriculture; cultivation of the Soil for1 food; farming, in the sense of operating land to raise provisions. Simons v. Lovell, 7 Heisk. (Tenn.) 516 ; McCue v. Tunstead, 65 Cal. 506, 4 Pac. 510

title: Husbreo
body: In Saxon law. The crime of housebreaking or burglary. Crabb, Eng. Law, 59, 308

title: Huscarle
body: In old English law. A house servant or domestic; a man of the household. Spelman

title: Husfastne
body: He who holds house and land. Bract L 3, L 2, c. 10

title: Husgablum
body: In oid records. House rent; or a tax or tribute laid upon a house. Cowell; Blount

title: Hush-Money
body: A colloquial expression to designate a bribe to hinder information; pay to secure silence

title: Hustings
body: Councll; court; tribunal. Apparently so called from belng held within a building, at a time -when other courts were held in the open air. It was a local court The county oourt in the city of London bore this name. There were hustings at York, winchester, Lincoln, and in other pla-ces similar to the London hustings. Also the raised place from which candidates for seats in parliament address the constituency, on the occasion of their nomination, whartpn

title: Hutesium Et Clamor
body: Hue and cry. See Hui ano Cbt

title: Hutilan
body: Taxes. Mon. Angl. 1. 586

title: Hwata, Hwatung
body: In old English law. Augury; divination

title: Hybernagium
body: In old English law. The season for sowing winter grain, between Michaelmas and Christmas. The lnnd on which such grain was sown. The grain It-self; winter grain or winter corn. Cowell

title: Hybrid
body: A mongrel; an animal foriu-ed of the nnlon of different species, or dif-ferent genera; also (metaphorically) a human being born of the union of persons of different races

title: Hydage
body: See Hidage

title: Hydrometer
body: An instrument for measuring the density of fluids. Being ira-mersed in fluids, as in water, brines beer, brandy, etc., it determines the proportion of thelr density, or their specific gravity, and thence their quality. See Rev. St U. S. S 2918 (U. S. Comp. St. 1901, p. 1927

title: Hyems, Hiems
body: Lat in the civU law. winter. Dig. 43, 20, 4, 34. written, in some of the old books, “perns.” Fleta, lib. 2, c. 73, SS 16, 18

title: Hypnotism
body: In medical jurisprudence. A psychic or mental state rendering the pa-tient susceptible to suggestion at the will of another

title: Hypobolum
body: In tbe civil law. The name of the bequest or legacy given by the husband to hls wife, at his death, above her dowry

title: Hypochondria
body: See Insanity

title: Hypostasis
body: In medical jurisprudence. (1) The morbid deposition of a sediment of any kind in the body. (2) A congestion or flushing of the blood vessels, as in varicose veins. Post-mortem hypostasis, a peculiar lividity of the cadaver

title: Hypotheo
body: In Scotland, the term “hypothec" is used to signify the landlord's right which, independently of any stipula-tlon, he has over the crop and stocking of his tenant. 'It gives a security to the landlord over the crop of each year for the lent of

title: Hyfotheca
body: “Hypotheca” was a term of the Roman law, and denoted a pledge or mortgage. As distinguished from the term “pignus" in the same law, it denoted a mortgage, whether of lands or of goods, in whlch the subject in pledge remained in the pos-sesslon of the mortgagor or debtor; whereas In the pignus the mortgagee or creditor was in tbe possession. Such an hypotheca might be either express or implied; express, where the parties upon the occasion of a loan en-tered into express agreement to that effect; or implied, as, e. g., in the case of the stock and utensils of a farmer, which were subject to the landlord’s right as a creditor for rent; wheuce the Scotch law of hypothec

title: Hypothecaria Actio
body: Lat in the

title: Hypothecarh Creditores
body: Lat

title: Hypothecary Action
body: The name of an action allowed under the civil law for the enforcement of the claims of a credit-or by the contract of hypotheca. Lovell v. Cragin, 136 U. S. 130, 10 Sup. CL 1024, 34 I* Ed. 372

title: Hypothecate
body: To pledge a thing without delivering the possession of it to the pledgee. “The master, when abroad, and in the absence of the owner, may hypothecate the ship, freight, and cargo, to raise money requisite for the completion of the voyage.” 3 Kent Comm. 171. See Spect v. Spect, 88 Cal. 437, 26 Pac. 203, 13 L. R. A. 137, 22 Am. St. Rep. 314; ogden v. Lathrop, 31 N. ¥. Super. Ct. 651

title: Hypothecation
body: A term borrowed from the civil law. In so far as It is nat-urailzed in English and American law, it means a contract of mortgage or pledge in

title: Hypothecation Bond
body: A bond giv-en in the contract of bottomfy or respondentia

title: Hypotheque
body: In French lnw. Hy-pothecatlon; a mortgage on real property; the right vested in a creditor by the assign-inent to hlm of real estate as security for the payment of hls debt, whether or not it be accompanied by possession. See Clv. Code La. art 3360

title: Hypothesis
body: A supposition, assumption, or theory; a theory set up by the pros-ecution, on a criminal trial, or by the de-fense, as on explanation of the facts in evi-dence, aud a ground for inferring guilt or ln-nocence, as the case may be, or as indicating a probable or posslble motive for tbe crlme

title: Hypothetical Question
body: A com-binatlon of assumed or proved facts and cir-cumstances, stated in such form as to constitute a coherent and specific situation or state of facts, upon whicli the oplnion of an expert is asked, by way of evldence on a trial. Howard v. People, 185 111. 552, 57 N. E. 441; People v. Durrant, 116 Cal. 216, 48 Pac. 85; Cowley v. People, 83 N. Y. 464. 38 Am. Rep. 464; Stearns v. Field, 90 N. Y. 641

title: Hyrnes
body: In old English law. A par* Ish

title: Hysteria
body: A paroxysmal disease or disorder of the nervous system, more common in females than males, not originating in any anatomical lesion, due- to psychic rather than physical causes, and attended, in the acute er convulsive form, by extraordinary manifesta-tions of secondary effects of extreme nervous-ness

title: Hysteropotmoi
body: Those who, hav-ing been thought dead, had, after a long absence in foreign countries, returned safely home; or those wbo, having been thought dead in battle, had afterwards unexpectedly escaped from thelr enemies and returned home. These, among the Romans, were not permitted to enter their own houses at the door, bnt were received at a passage opened in the roof. Enc. Lond

title: Hysterotomy
body: The Caesarean opera-tion. See Cjksabeaw Sbction

title: Hythe
body: In English law. A port, wharf, or small haven to embark or land merchandise at Cowell; Blount

title: Habeas corpus
body: Latin, meaning "you have the body." A writ of habeas corpus generally is a judicial order forcing law enforcement authorities to produce a prisoner they are holding, and to justify the prisoner's continued confinement. Federal judges receive petitions for a writ of habeas corpus from state prison inmates who say their state prosecutions violated federally protected rights in some way.

title: Hearsay
body: Evidence presented by a witness who did not see or hear the incident in question but heard about it from someone else. With some exceptions, hearsay generally is not admissible as evidence at trial

title: Home confinement
body: A special condition the court imposes that requires an individual to remain at home except for certain approved activities such as work and medical appointments. Home confinement may include the use of electronic monitoring equipment – a transmitter attached to the wrist or the ankle – to help ensure that the person stays at home as required.
